questions.question_text_1: A firm has a return on equity of 25 percent. The total asset turnover is 2.4 and the profit margin is 8 percent. The total equity is ₹ 4,100. What is the net income?
question_texts: A firm has a return on equity of 25 percent. The total asset turnover is 2.4 and the profit margin is 8 percent. The total equity is ₹ 4,100. What is the net income?

questions.question_text_1: A firm has net working capital of ₹ 580, net fixed assets of ₹ 2,326, sales of ₹ 6,900, and current liabilities of ₹ 890. How many rupees worth of sales is generated from every ₹ 1 in total assets?
question_texts: A firm has net working capital of ₹ 580, net fixed assets of ₹ 2,326, sales of ₹ 6,900, and current liabilities of ₹ 890. How many rupees worth of sales is generated from every ₹ 1 in total assets?

questions.question_text_1: Mario's Home Systems has sales of ₹ 2,820, costs of goods sold of ₹ 2,160, inventory of ₹ 504, and accounts receivable of ₹ 430. How many days, on average, does it take Mario's to sell its inventory?
question_texts: Mario's Home Systems has sales of ₹ 2,820, costs of goods sold of ₹ 2,160, inventory of ₹ 504, and accounts receivable of ₹ 430. How many days, on average, does it take Mario's to sell its inventory?

questions.question_text_1: Frederico's has a net income of ₹ 29,600, a total asset turnover of 1.4, total assets of ₹ 3,18,600, and a debt-equity ratio of .35. What is the return on equity?
question_texts: Frederico's has a net income of ₹ 29,600, a total asset turnover of 1.4, total assets of ₹ 3,18,600, and a debt-equity ratio of .35. What is the return on equity?

questions.question_text_1: Catherine's Consulting paid dividends of ₹ 3,300 and total equity of ₹ 39,450. The debt-equity ratio is 1 and the retention ratio is 40 percent. What is the return on assets?
question_texts: Catherine's Consulting paid dividends of ₹ 3,300 and total equity of ₹ 39,450. The debt-equity ratio is 1 and the retention ratio is 40 percent. What is the return on assets?

questions.question_text_1: Southern Foods has net income of ₹ 39,900, net sales of ₹ 3,18,600, total assets of ₹ 6,63,000, common stock of ₹ 1,06,800 with a par value of ₹1 per share, and retained earnings of ₹ 2,24,400. The stock has a market value of ₹ 5.45 per share. What is the price-earnings ratio?
question_texts: Southern Foods has net income of ₹ 39,900, net sales of ₹ 3,18,600, total assets of ₹ 6,63,000, common stock of ₹ 1,06,800 with a par value of ₹1 per share, and retained earnings of ₹ 2,24,400. The stock has a market value of ₹ 5.45 per share. What is the price-earnings ratio?

questions.question_text_1: Mohan will receive a perpetuity of ₹ 30,000 per year forever, while Rohan will receive the same annual payment for the next 30 years. If the interest rate is 7.4 percent, how much more are Mohan’s payments worth?
question_texts: Mohan will receive a perpetuity of ₹ 30,000 per year forever, while Rohan will receive the same annual payment for the next 30 years. If the interest rate is 7.4 percent, how much more are Mohan’s payments worth?

questions.question_text_1: Your grandparents would like to establish a trust fund that will pay you and your heirs ₹ 2,05,000 per year forever with the first payment 12 years from today. If the trust fund earns an annual return of 4 percent, how much must your grandparents deposit today?
question_texts: Your grandparents would like to establish a trust fund that will pay you and your heirs ₹ 2,05,000 per year forever with the first payment 12 years from today. If the trust fund earns an annual return of 4 percent, how much must your grandparents deposit today?

questions.question_text_1: An annuity costs ₹ 70,000 today, pays ₹ 3,500 a year, and earns a return of 4.5 percent. What is the length of the annuity time period?
question_texts: An annuity costs ₹ 70,000 today, pays ₹ 3,500 a year, and earns a return of 4.5 percent. What is the length of the annuity time period?

questions.question_text_1: Nu-Tools plans to set aside an equal amount of money each year, starting today, so that it will have ₹ 25,000 saved at the end of three years. If the firm can earn 4.7 percent, how much does it have to save annually?
question_texts: Nu-Tools plans to set aside an equal amount of money each year, starting today, so that it will have ₹ 25,000 saved at the end of three years. If the firm can earn 4.7 percent, how much does it have to save annually?

questions.question_text_1: Blink of an Eye Company is evaluating a 5-year project that will provide cash flows of ₹ 34,500, ₹ 55,950, ₹ 62,210, ₹ 59,930, and ₹ 42,910, respectively. The project has an initial cost of ₹149,920 and the required return is 8 percent. What is the project's NPV?

questions.question_text_1: According to the CAPM, the expected return on a security is:
question_texts: According to the CAPM, the expected return on a security is:

options.option_text: Negatively and non-linearly related to the security's beta.
Positively and linearly related to the security's variance.
Positively and non-linearly related to the security's beta.
Positively and linearly related to the security's beta.

questions.question_text_1: Phil's Carvings wants to have a weighted average cost of capital of 9.5 percent. The firm has an after-tax cost of debt of 6.5 percent and a cost of equity of 12.75 percent. What debt-equity ratio is needed for the firm to achieve its targeted weighted average cost of capital?
question_texts: Phil's Carvings wants to have a weighted average cost of capital of 9.5 percent. The firm has an after-tax cost of debt of 6.5 percent and a cost of equity of 12.75 percent. What debt-equity ratio is needed for the firm to achieve its targeted weighted average cost of capital?

question_texts: What is the cost of equity for a firm that has a beta of 1.2 if the risk-free rate of return is 2.9 percent and the expected market return is 11.4 percent?

questions.question_text_1: What is the relationship between the IRR and the cost of capital?
question_texts: What is the relationship between the IRR and the cost of capital?

options.option_text: The IRR must be lower than the cost of capital for the investment to beprofitable.
The IRR must be higher than the cost of capital for the investment to beprofitable.
The IRR and cost of capital are unrelated.
The IRR and cost of capital have an inverse relationship.

questions.question_text_1:
After missing 4 consecutive payments, a customer paid back the missed instalments in the 5th
month. Has the customer rolled back or rolled forward?
question_texts:
After missing 4 consecutive payments, a customer paid back the missed instalments in the 5th
month. Has the customer rolled back or rolled forward?

options.option_text: Both Roll back and Roll forward

options.option_text: The model is performing well and can continue to be used
The population started to change and should plan for a new model or modelrefresh
The population significantly changed, and the model needs to be retiredimmediately
Higher the PSI, better the model performance

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### Financial Ratios and Metrics
1. **Return on Equity (ROE)**
   - Formula: \( \text{ROE} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Equity}} \)

2. **Total Asset Turnover**
   - Formula: \( \text{Total Asset Turnover} = \frac{\text{Sales}}{\text{Total Assets}} \)

3. **Profit Margin**
   - Formula: \( \text{Profit Margin} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Sales}} \)

4. **Debt-Equity Ratio**
   - Formula: \( \text{Debt-Equity Ratio} = \frac{\text{Total Debt}}{\text{Total Equity}} \)

5. **Retention Ratio**
   - Formula: \( \text{Retention Ratio} = 1 - \text{Dividend Payout Ratio} \)

6. **Return on Assets (ROA)**
   - Formula: \( \text{ROA} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Assets}} \)

7. **Price-Earnings Ratio (P/E Ratio)**
   - Formula: \( \text{P/E Ratio} = \frac{\text{Market Value per Share}}{\text{Earnings per Share}} \)

#### Time Value of Money
1. **Perpetuity**
   - Formula: \( \text{Present Value of Perpetuity} = \frac{\text{Annual Payment}}{\text{Interest Rate}} \)

2. **Annuity**
   - Formula: \( \text{Present Value of Annuity} = \text{Annual Payment} \times \frac{1 - (1 + \text{Interest Rate})^{-n}}{\text{Interest Rate}} \)

3. **Future Value of Annuity**
   - Formula: \( \text{Future Value of Annuity} = \text{Annual Payment} \times \frac{(1 + \text{Interest Rate})^n - 1}{\text{Interest Rate}} \)

#### Capital Budgeting
1. **Net Present Value (NPV)**
   - Formula: \( \text{NPV} = \sum_{t=0}^{n} \frac{\text{Cash Flow}_t}{(1 + \text{Discount Rate})^t} - \text{Initial Investment} \)

2. **Internal Rate of Return (IRR)**
   - Definition: The discount rate that makes the NPV of all cash flows equal to zero.

#### Financial Models
1. **Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM)**
   - Formula: \( \text{Expected Return} = \text{Risk-Free Rate} + \beta \times (\text{Market Return} - \text{Risk-Free Rate}) \)

2. **Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC)**
   - Formula: \( \text{WACC} = \frac{\text{Equity}}{\text{Total Capital}} \times \text{Cost of Equity} + \frac{\text{Debt}}{\text{Total Capital}} \times \text{Cost of Debt} \times (1 - \text{Tax Rate}) \)

#### Financial Forensics and Risk Management
1. **Roll Rate Analysis**
   - Definition: Analyzing the movement of customers between different delinquency states over time.

2. **Reject Inferencing**
   - Definition: Identifying potential default applications from declined applications.

3. **Population Stability Index (PSI)**
   - Definition: Measures the stability of a population over time.

4. **Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) Statistic**
   - Definition: Measures the degree of separation between two distributions.

5. **Information Value (IV)**
   - Definition: Measures the predictive power of a variable.

6. **Weight of Evidence (WoE)**
   - Definition: Measures the predictive power of a variable in a model.

### Mermaid Knowledge Graph

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Financial Ratios] --> B[Return on Equity]
    A --> C[Total Asset Turnover]
    A --> D[Profit Margin]
    A --> E[Debt-Equity Ratio]
    A --> F[Retention Ratio]
    A --> G[Return on Assets]
    A --> H[Price-Earnings Ratio]

    I[Time Value of Money] --> J[Perpetuity]
    I --> K[Annuity]
    I --> L[Future Value of Annuity]

    M[Capital Budgeting] --> N[Net Present Value]
    M --> O[Internal Rate of Return]

    P[Financial Models] --> Q[Capital Asset Pricing Model]
    P --> R[Weighted Average Cost of Capital]

    S[Financial Forensics] --> T[Roll Rate Analysis]
    S --> U[Reject Inferencing]
    S --> V[Population Stability Index]
    S --> W[Kolmogorov-Smirnov Statistic]
    S --> X[Information Value]
    S --> Y[Weight of Evidence]
```

```mermaid
graph TD;
    B[Return on Equity] --> Z[Net Income]
    B --> AA[Total Equity]

    C[Total Asset Turnover] --> AB[Sales]
    C --> AC[Total Assets]

    D[Profit Margin] --> AD[Net Income]
    D --> AB[Sales]

    E[Debt-Equity Ratio] --> AE[Total Debt]
    E --> AA[Total Equity]

    F[Retention Ratio] --> AF[Dividend Payout Ratio]

    G[Return on Assets] --> Z[Net Income]
    G --> AC[Total Assets]

    H[Price-Earnings Ratio] --> AG[Market Value per Share]
    H --> AH[Earnings per Share]

    J[Perpetuity] --> AI[Annual Payment]
    J --> AJ[Interest Rate]

    K[Annuity] --> AI[Annual Payment]
    K --> AJ[Interest Rate]
    K --> AK[Number of Periods]

    L[Future Value of Annuity] --> AI[Annual Payment]
    L --> AJ[Interest Rate]
    L --> AK[Number of Periods]

    N[Net Present Value] --> AL[Cash Flows]
    N --> AM[Discount Rate]
    N --> AN[Initial Investment]

    O[Internal Rate of Return] --> AL[Cash Flows]
    O --> AN[Initial Investment]

    Q[Capital Asset Pricing Model] --> AO[Risk-Free Rate]
    Q --> AP[Beta]
    Q --> AQ[Market Return]

    R[Weighted Average Cost of Capital] --> AR[Equity]
    R --> AS[Cost of Equity]
    R --> AT[Debt]
    R --> AU[Cost of Debt]
    R --> AV[Tax Rate]
```

This summary and the knowledge graphs provide a clear and structured overview of the core topics, concepts, principles, and equations essential for the exam on Financial Forensics.
